channel.title: tastytrade: Options Jive
channel.description: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Learn to talk the talk - sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss trading topics of the day.
channel.itunes:author: tastytrade
channel.itunes:summary: If you want to trade like a tastytrader, you have to learn how to talk like a tastytrader. Sit down with Tom and Tony as they dish out and discuss popular trading topics that give you an edge when opening, closing and managing your trades.
channel.googleplay:author: tastytrade, Inc.

item.title: The Optimum Time to Sell Earnings Volatility
item.description:
Quarterly earnings provide the perfect opportunity for tastytraders to get short volatility. The binary event of stock moment and IV crush is ripe for profitability provided the stock does not move too much. However, can one sell earnings volatility too early? Is there an optimum time to sell?

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they discuss the optimum time to sell earnings volatility.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Quarterly earnings provide the perfect opportunity for tastytraders to get short volatility. The binary event of stock moment and IV crush is ripe for profitability provided the stock does not move too much. However, can one sell earnings volatili...

item.title: Crypto at All Time High
item.description:
The leading cryptos (BTC and ETH) are trading near all time highs while their IVs, expected moves, and price volatilities remain constant.

Volatility of the crypto space is around the same as natural gas and around 5 to 6x that of the equity markets.

item.title: Advanced Expected Moves
item.description: Looking at the expected move can be a crucial first step when it comes to picking which strikes to trade. Today, Tom and Tony explore a more sophisticated method for reaching the expected range of an underlying, using only tools readily available in the platform.

item.title: Earnings Season and Sector ETFs
item.description:
Sector ETFs that are comprised of the 11 S&P 500 sectors are a good way to diversify a portfolio. Additionally, they can be used during earnings season in a myriad of ways to help offset single stock risk.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they take a look at some stats on the 11 S&P 500 sector ETFs.

item.title: Skew and IV Correlation
item.description:
Option skew can be intuitively thought of as the direction and magnitude of the underlying’s velocity of risk. For equities, this risk is to the downside whereas commodities see their velocity of risk to the upside.

The direction of the underlying’s velocity of risk can be determined by either looking at the symmetry of the option chain, or by observing the correlation between the underlying’s price and its IV.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: Option skew can be intuitively thought of as the direction and magnitude of the underlying’s velocity of risk. For equities, this risk is to the downside whereas commodities see their velocity of risk to the upside. The direction of the underlying...

item.title: Consistency of Probabilities
item.description:
tastytraders rely on implied volatilities and expected moves in order to decide which trades to put on. 

Today, TP and Tony look at the data to see how reliable the probabilities around expected moves really are.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade
item.itunes:subtitle: tastytraders rely on implied volatilities and expected moves in order to decide which trades to put on. Today, TP and Tony look at the data to see how reliable the probabilities around expected moves really are.

item.title: Why Options Volume and Open Interest are Important
item.description:
Volume and open interest are key indicators that provide information on liquidity and options activity. Understanding these two metrics can add to a trader’s overall market awareness.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they tackle open interest, volume, liquidity and take a look at a few examples.

item.title: Set Up a Broken Wing Butterfly
item.description:
Broken wing butterflies are a low cost, high probability trade that have of characteristics jade lizards and iron condors.

A common purpose for BWBs is when you want a defined risk trade that targets a neutral range above or below the current underlying price. 

We would use OTM calls to target a range above the underlying price and OTM puts for a range below the underlying price.

Tune in for more on this popular options trading strategy.

item.title: Symmetry with Skew
item.description: Due to volatility skew, a delta neutral iron condor typically has wings of unequal strike width. BPR, however, is determined by the wider of the two wings. Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see if we can squeeze a little more buying power efficiency from our positions if we are willing to accept some delta risk.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: Volatility Index and Indicator Review
item.description:
Tom & Tony list and define the various volatility products and indicators to help traders get a feel for market "fear," option prices, and more.

  • VIX: Cash settled S&P 500 Volatility Index based on SPX index options 30 days forward
  • /VX: S&P Volatility Future
  • /VXM: Micro future 1/10 the size of /VX
  • VXX: Most actively traded Volatility ETF
  • VVIX: Represents volatility on volatility looking forward 30 days
  • SKEW: Measure of potential risk and investor sentiment targeting tail risk

item.title: The Nature of Natural Gas
item.description:
With months to go before peak U.S. consumption, natural gas has been surging in price. The rise comes on the heels of high summer temperatures in the northern hemisphere and shut-ins after hurricane Ida. Now, the focus is on the spread between March and April natural gas futures, which is a bet on how tight supplies will be at the end of the North American winter.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they discuss the recent volatility in natural gas and analyze the prospects of a volatile winter.

item.title: When To Roll
item.description:
Rolling is more an art than a definite science. Some traders prefer not to roll at all for simplicity while others want to have a stronger grip on their delta risk.

For those who want to have a starting benchmark for trade adjustment, consider rolling the untested side of a trade back to its starting delta when the delta of the tested side grows by 50%.

item.title: Expirations vs. Earnings
item.description: Earnings announcements make for excellent opportunities to sell premium, expecting volatility to come down afterwards. Monthly expiration dates can have similar effects on volatility. Today, Tom and Tony look at the data to see how the volatility effects from expiration stack up against those from earnings.
item.itunes:author: tastytrade

item.title: Friends of the 10-Year Yield
item.description:
After initially dropping in the wake of Wednesday’s FOMC rate decision, 10-year yields are decidedly higher in the past few trading sessions. The market seems to be pricing in a chance that the Fed will announce the tapering of its bond purchases in November. This could have an impact on certain sectors of the market.

Join Tom, Tony and Jermal as they check to see which sectors are friendly to the move up in 10-year yields.
